title: Target big-spending Millennials to lift hotel rates: report
text:
Hotel owners and operators looking to boost returns could do so by appealing to Millennials – or Gen Y – with a new report showing they are willing to spend more on hotel accommodation then Gen X and Baby Boomers.

The report, by CBRE, found Millennials – those aged between 24 and 39, and previously chided for their willingness to spend big on smashed avo on toast rather than save for a home deposit – spent on average $234 per capita per year on accommodation between 2014 and 2018.

Hotels like Marriot's Moxy appeal to younger travelers and are coming to Australia

By comparison, Generation X (aged 40 to 54) spent $231 per capita per year on accommodation while tight-fisted Baby Boomers (aged 55 to 73) spent a paltry $165.

The challenge for hoteliers is to lure Millennials from the more homely, eclectic and affordable Airbnb-style accommodation favoured by them and their younger cohorts, the post-Millennials, born from 1997 onwards.

According to the CBRE research, post-Millennials and Millennials make up a significantly higher share of total nights spent in private rentals such as Airbnb (56 per cent) relative to total nights spent in hotel accommodation (38 per cent).
description: Millennials spent more on hotel accommodation then both Gen X and Baby Boomers, but have a preference for Airbnb, according to a new CBRE report.
